member.name: T:LamestWebserver.Core.ElevateRightsWindows
member.summary:
Tools for executing the current Application with elevated rights
Source: https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/windowsapps/CSUACSelfElevation-644673d3

member.name: P:LamestWebserver.Core.ElevateRightsWindows.IsRunAsAdmin
member.summary: The function checks whether the current process is run as administrator. In other words, it dictates whether the primary access token of the process belongs to user account that is a member of the local Administrators group and it is elevated.
member.returns: Returns true if the primary access token of the process belongs to user account that is a member of the local Administrators group and it is elevated. Returns false if the token does not.

member.name: P:LamestWebserver.Core.ElevateRightsWindows.IsProcessElevated
member.summary: The function gets the elevation information of the current process. It dictates whether the process is elevated or not. Token elevation is only available on Windows Vista and newer operating systems, thus IsProcessElevated throws a C++ exception if it is called on systems prior to Windows Vista. It is not appropriate to use this function to determine whether a process is run as administartor.
member.returns: Returns true if the process is elevated. Returns false if it is not.
member.exception: When any native Windows API call fails, the function throws a Win32Exception with the last error code.
member.remarks: TOKEN_INFORMATION_CLASS provides TokenElevationType to check the elevation type (TokenElevationTypeDefault / TokenElevationTypeLimited / TokenElevationTypeFull) of the process. It is different from TokenElevation in that, when UAC is turned off, elevation type always returns TokenElevationTypeDefault even though the process is elevated (Integrity Level == High). In other words, it is not safe to say if the process is elevated based on elevation type. Instead, we should use TokenElevation.

member.name: M:LamestWebserver.Core.ElevateRightsWindows.ElevateRights
member.summary: Reexecutes the current process with administrative rights and exits the current one if you don't already have these

member.summary: The function retrieves a specified type of information about an access token. The calling process must have appropriate access rights to obtain the information.

member.name: M:LamestWebserver.Core.NativeMethods.GetSidSubAuthority(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: The function returns a pointer to a specified subauthority in a security identifier (SID). The subauthority value is a relative identifier (RID).
member.param: A pointer to the SID structure from which a pointer to a subauthority is to be returned.
Specifies an index value identifying the subauthority array element whose address the function will return.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is a pointer to the specified SID subauthority. To get extended error information, call GetLastError. If the function fails, the return value is undefined. The function fails if the specified SID structure is not valid or if the index value specified by the nSubAuthority parameter is out of bounds.
